qas.question: Many holds will leave what body parts free?
When must contact stop between wrestlers?

answers.text: if any part of the body is touching, or underneath, the ropes,

qas.question: How might a wrestler attempt to break a submission hold?

answers.text: by deliberately grabbing the bottom ropes

qas.question: How long does a wrestler have to get themselves free of the hold?
What happens if the wrestler doesn't break a hold?

context: Since all contact between the wrestlers must cease <a1_0>if any part of the body is touching, or underneath, the ropes,<a1_0/> many wrestlers will attempt to break submission holds <a2_0>by deliberately grabbing the bottom ropes<a2_0/>. This is called a "rope break", and it is one of the most common ways to break a submission hold. Most holds leave <a0_0>an arm or leg<a0_0/> free, so that the person can tap out if they want. Instead, they use these free limbs to either grab one of the ring ropes (the bottom one is the most common, as it is nearest the wrestlers, though other ropes sometimes are used for standing holds such as Chris Masters' Master Lock) or drape their foot across, or underneath one. Once this has been accomplished, and the accomplishment is witnessed by the referee, the referee will demand that the offending wrestler break the hold, and start counting to five if the wrestler does not. If the referee reaches <a3_0>the count of five<a3_0/>, and the wrestler still does not break the hold, <a4_0>they are disqualified<a4_0/>.
